facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 123 and 124 of 1966 were filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 123 and 124 of 1966.

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from judgments and orders dated April 28, 1965 of Gujarat High Court in Civil Revision Applications Nos. 88 and 93 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgments and orders dated April 28, 1965 of the Gujarat High Court in Civil Revision Applications Nos. 88 and 93 of 1961.

facts.text: Two applications in High Court arose out of proceedings under Saurashtra Agricultural Debtors Relief Act.

anchor.surface_text: The two applications in the High Court arose out of certain proceedings under the Saurashtra Agricultural Debtors Relief Act.

facts.text: Appellants were mortgagees in possession of lands belonging to debtors represented by respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The applicants before the High Court and the appellants before this Court were mortgagees in possession of certain lands belonging to the debtors who are now represented by the respondents.

facts.text: Creditors (appellants) in possession under two mortgage deeds of Samvat years 1997 (Rs. 991) and 1999 (Rs. 1,011).

anchor.surface_text: The creditors, appellants before us, were in possession of the properties- the subject matter of litigation, under two mortgage deeds of Samvat years 1997 and 1999. The first mortgage was for Rs. 991 and the second for Rs, 1,011

facts.text: Mortgagees have been appropriating income of usufruct for last 50 years.

anchor.surface_text: The mortgagees were with possession and the mortgagee have been appropriating the income of the usufruct thereof for the last 50 years.

facts.text: Mortgagees paying revenue and other dues to State for many years, no dispute.

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing to show whether they were under a liability under the documents of mortgage to pay the revenue and other dues to the State but there is no dispute that they have been doing so for many years past.

facts.text: Lands situate in Bajana State with Girasdari system.

anchor.surface_text: The lands were situate in Bajana State with its own peculiar land tenure system known as the Girasdari system.

facts.text: Saurashtra Land Reforms Act, XXV of 1951 came into force on July 23, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The Land Reforms Act which came into force on July 23, 1951 purported to effect important and far-reaching changes in the said system.

facts.text: Mamlatdar order dated 16th January 1954 (Ex. 8/1): Girasdar allowed Gharkhed certain lands, S. Nos. 684 and 685 khalsa held by mortgagees, full assessment, no occupancy rights.

anchor.surface_text: The copy of the order on the respondents application marked Ex. 8/1 bearing date 16th January 1954 was handed over to us. It appears therefrom that the Girasdar was allowed to keep as Gharkhed certain lands by paying six times the assessment in the treasury but with regard to S. Nos. 684 arid 685  the lands given to the mortgagees  the same were held by the Mamlatdar to be khalsa and full assessment thereof was ordered to be taken. The Mamlatdar further noted that there was no need to grant any occupancy rights.

facts.text: Respondents applied on May 2, 1955 for adjustment of debt to Civil Judge under Debtors Relief Act.

anchor.surface_text: On May 2, 1955 the respondents applied for adjustment of their debt to the Civil Judge exercising jurisdiction under the Debtors Relief Act.

facts.text: Creditors relied on Mamlatdar order declaring lands khalsa and Bhayati court decision.

anchor.surface_text: The creditors relied on the order of the Special Mamlatdar declaring the lands as Khalsa as fortified by the decision of the Bhayati court of Bajana State.

facts.text: Bhayati court decided Bajana State had no title or interest, Jats Mul-Girasdars independent proprietors.

anchor.surface_text: According to the Civil Judge the judgment of the Bhayati court had merely decided that the Bajana State had no title or interest in the land in question and that the Jats Mul-Girasdars were independent proprietors thereof.

facts.text: Civil Judge directed restoration of lands to debtors subject to limitations and conditions.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the Civil Judge directed the restoration of the lands to the debtors subject to certain limitations and conditions.

facts.text: Creditors appealed to Assistant Judge, Surendranagar.

anchor.surface_text: The creditors went up in appeal to the Assistant Judge, Surendranagar.

facts.text: Assistant Judge held mortgages not extinguished, ordered debtors pay Rs. 1,698 in twelve yearly instalments.

anchor.surface_text: Dealing, with the question of the advances made and the amounts still due to the creditors, it was ordered that the debtors should pay Rs. 1,698/- in twelve yearly instalments and the award was directed to be modified accordingly.

facts.text: Gujarat High Court affirmed Assistant Judge order directing possession to debtors.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the High Court affirmed the order of the Assistant Judge in appeal directing possession to be handed over to the debtors.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Special Mamlatdar had no jurisdiction to terminate mortgage rights.

anchor.surface_text: The said Officer had no jurisdiction to terminate any rights under mortgage, ... In our view all that the Special Mamlatdar decided and had jurisdiction to decide under the Act was, whether the debtors could be given occupancy certificates or allotted any land Gharkhed

facts.text: Debtors' rights in lands not extinguished under Land Reforms Act.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the right of the debtors in this case were not extinguished under the Land Reforms Act

facts.text: Court under Debtors Relief Act can scale down debt and restore possession to mortgagors.

anchor.surface_text: it was open to the court exercising jurisdiction under the Debtors Relief Act to scale down the debt and provide for restoration of the land in possession of the mortgagees to the mortgagors
Appeals by special leave from the judgments and orders dated April 28, 1965 of the Gujarat High Court in Civil Revision Applications Nos. 88 and 93 of 1961.
The two applications in the High Court arose out of certain proceedings under the Saurashtra Agricultural Debtors Relief Act.

concepts.unlisted_label: Saurashtra Land Reforms Act, XXV of 1951
concepts.unlisted_description: Act to improve land revenue administration, end Girasdari system, grant occupancy rights to tenants.

anchor.surface_text: Under S. 2 15  Girasdar meant any talukdar, bhagdar, bhayat, cadet or mul-girasia, etc.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 2(15) Saurashtra Land Reforms Act (definition of Girasdar)

anchor.surface_text: Under S. 2 13  estate meant all land of whatever description held by a Girasdar including uncultivable waste whether used for the purpose of agriculture or not

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 2(13) Saurashtra Land Reforms Act (definition of estate)

anchor.surface_text: A tenant under S. 2 30  meant an agriculturist who held land on lease from a Girasdar or a person claiming through him and included a person who was deemed to be a tenant under the provisions of the Act.

concepts.interpretation: Mortgagee in possession not a tenant.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 2(30) Saurashtra Land Reforms Act (definition of tenant)

anchor.surface_text: Under S. 3 the provisions of the Act were to have effect notwithstanding anything inconsistent therewith contained in any other law for the time being in force.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 3 Saurashtra Land Reforms Act (overriding effect)

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 1  of the Act laid down that any person who was lawfully cultivating any land belonging to a Girasdar was to be deemed for the purposes of the Act to be the tenant if he was not a member of the Girasdars family or a servant on wages payable in cash or in kind etc. or a mortgagee in, possession.

concepts.interpretation: Mortgagee in possession excluded from being deemed tenant; explanation confirms mortgagee does not cease to be tenant only on that ground but cannot become tenant.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ng on the parties and number having gone up in appeal from the order of the Special Mamlatdar the debtors companyld number be allowed to agitate their

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 6 Saurashtra Land Reforms Act (deemed tenant)
concepts.unlisted_description: Provision deeming cultivators as tenants, excluding mortgagees.

anchor.surface_text: The functions of a Mamlatdar are laid down in S. 46 of the Act. It was for him to decide inter alia what land should be allotted to a Girasdar for personal cultivation and to make such allotment, to decide whether a person was or was not tenant,

concepts.interpretation: Extinguishment applies to Girasdar's rights upon compensation payment, not to mortgagor-mortgagee rights.

issues.text: whether the debtors had lost all their interest in the lands mortgaged by reason of the operation of the Saurashtra Land Reforms Act, XXV of 1951 and as such were not competent to make an application under the Saurashtra Agricultural Debtors Relief Act, 1954

anchor.surface_text: The main question before the High Court was and before us is, whether the debtors had lost all their interest in the lands mortgaged by reason of the operation of the Saurashtra Land Reforms Act, XXV of 1951 and as such were not competent to make an application under the

issues.text: whether the decision of the Special Mamlatdar was binding on the parties inter se mortgagor and mortgagee and the debtors could not agitate their rights ignoring the said order

anchor.surface_text: Before us great stress was laid on the decision of the Special Mamlatdar and it was argued that subject to any appeal from his order his decision was binding on the parties and not having gone up in appeal from the order of the Special Mamlatdar the debtors could not be allowed to agitate their rights to the land ignoring the said order.

issues.text: whether the Special Mamlatdar had jurisdiction to terminate any rights under mortgage or decide rights inter se between mortgagor and mortgagee

anchor.surface_text: The above analysis of the relevant provisions of the Land Reforms Act amply demonstrates the manner in which a change was to be brought about in the relationship between the Girasdar and his tenants and the rights which they were respectively to acquire under the orders of the Special Mamlatdar. The said Officer had no jurisdiction to terminate any rights under mortgage,

issues.text: whether the mortgagees in possession were tenants or deemed tenants under Section 6 of the Saurashtra Land Reforms Act

anchor.surface_text: In order to get such occupancy rights the creditors had to show that they had become tenants which Obviously they could not be under the provisions of S. 6 of the Land Reforms Act.

issues.text: whether payments of revenue by mortgagees in possession confer title or rights in derogation of the mortgagors

anchor.surface_text: Under S. 76 c of the Transfer of Property Act a mortgagee in possession must, in the absence of a contract to the contrary out of the income of the property, pay the Government revenue, all other charges of a public nature ... the mortgagees were only entitled under s. 72 b of the Transfer of Property Act to add the amount to the mortgage money. They could not by paying such rent or revenue acquire a title in derogation of the rights of the mortgagors

issues.text: whether the provisions of the Debtors Relief Act override those in the Land Reforms Act
whether the mortgagors as C class Girasdars can retain land in excess of the limits specified in the Land Reforms Act upon restoration

arguments.claim: Provisions of Debtors Relief Act being subsequent prevail over Land Reforms Act

anchor.surface_text: It was not necessary to test the correctness of the decision of the Special Mamlatdar as in view of the provisions in the Debtors Relief Act which was an Act subsequent to the Land Reforms Act the provisions of the latter Act were to prevail.

arguments.court_reasoning: Not necessary to decide as debtors' rights not extinguished under Land Reforms Act

arguments.claim: Special Mamlatdar had no jurisdiction to terminate rights under mortgage or decide inter se rights between mortgagor and mortgagee

anchor.surface_text: The said Officer had no jurisdiction to terminate any rights under mortgage, ... In our view all that the Special Mamlatdar decided and had jurisdiction to decide under the Act was, whether the debtors could be given occupancy certificates or allotted any land Gharkhed

arguments.claim: Mortgagees in possession were not tenants or deemed tenants under Section 6 of Saurashtra Land Reforms Act

anchor.surface_text: In order to get such occupancy rights the creditors had to show that they had become tenants which Obviously they could not be under the provisions of S. 6 of the Land Reforms Act.

arguments.claim: Payments of revenue by mortgagees do not confer title or rights in derogation of mortgagors per TPA Sections 76(c) and 72(b)

anchor.surface_text: Under S. 76 c  of the Transfer of Property Act a mortgagee in possession must, in the absence of a contract to the contrary out of the income of the property, pay the Government revenue... the mortgagees were only entitled under s. 72 b  of the Transfer of Property Act to add the amount to the mortgage money. They could not by paying such rent or revenue acquire a title in derogation of the rights of the mortgagors

arguments.claim: Debtors' rights in lands not extinguished under Land Reforms Act

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the right of the debtors in this case were not extinguished under the Land Reforms Act

arguments.claim: Court under Debtors Relief Act can scale down debt and restore possession to mortgagors after accounting

anchor.surface_text: it was open to the court exercising jurisdiction under the Debtors Relief Act to scale down the debt and provide for restoration of the land in possession of the mortgagees to the mortgagors

arguments.claim: Land Reforms Act aimed at regulating Girasdars and tenants, not extinguishing mortgagor rights unless occupants became tenants

anchor.surface_text: It will be noted at once that the Act aimed at regulating the relationship of persons in the position of landholders and their tenants and to enable the tenants to become the real owners of the soil under direct tenancy from the State. It was not meant to extinguish or affect the rights of the landholders as mortgagors unless the persons- in occupation had become tenants either by contract or by operation of law.

arguments.claim: No compensation paid to debtors for khalsa lands, so no extinguishment

anchor.surface_text: That apart, it has not been shown to us that the debtors were awarded any compensation in respect of the khalsa lands given in mortgage to the appellants.

arguments.claim: Occupancy certificates under Land Reforms Act cannot extinguish title of mortgagors

anchor.surface_text: The occupancy certificates, if any, given by the Special Mamlatdar to the appellants cannot under the provisions of the Land Reforms Act extinguish the title of the mortgagors.

holdings.text: The Special Mamlatdar had no jurisdiction to terminate any rights under mortgage or decide rights inter se between mortgagor and mortgagee.

anchor.surface_text: The said Officer had no jurisdiction to terminate any rights under mortgage, ... In our view all that the Special Mamlatdar decided and had jurisdiction to decide under the Act was, whether the debtors could be given occupancy certificates or allotted any land Gharkhed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analysis of Land Reforms Act provisions (Ss. 2,6,19,20,24,31,36,46) shows changes limited to Girasdar-tenant relationships; Mamlatdar functions do not extend to mortgage rights.

holdings.text: The decision of the Special Mamlatdar was not binding on parties inter se mortgagor and mortgagee as it lacked jurisdiction and full text unavailable.

anchor.surface_text: We have not before us the full text of the order of the Special Mamlatdar relied on by the appellants nor are we satisfied from copies of form 7 ...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mamlatdar only decided on occupancy/Gharkhed; no jurisdiction over mortgage rights; res judicata inapplicable without jurisdiction.

holdings.text: Mortgagees in possession were not tenants or deemed tenants under Section 6 of the Land Reforms Act and could not obtain occupancy rights thereunder.

anchor.surface_text: In order to get such occupancy rights the creditors had to show that they had become tenants which Obviously they could not be under the provisions of S. 6 of the Land Reforms Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.6 expressly excludes mortgagee in possession from deemed tenant status; Explanation does not make mortgagee a tenant.

holdings.text: Payments of revenue and dues by mortgagees in possession do not confer title or rights in derogation of mortgagors under Transfer of Property Act Ss.76(c) and 72(b).

anchor.surface_text: Under S. 76 c of the Transfer of Property Act a mortgagee in possession must, in the absence of a contract to the contrary out of the income of the property, pay the Government revenue...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mortgagee duty to pay from income or add to principal; cannot acquire adverse title.

holdings.text: No compensation was awarded to debtors for khalsa lands, supporting non-extinguishment of their rights.

anchor.surface_text: That apart, it has not been shown to us that the debtors were awarded any compensation in respect of the khalsa lands given in mortgage to the appellants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of evidence of compensation payment; S.36 extinguishment tied to compensation.

holdings.text: Occupancy certificates given by Special Mamlatdar to mortgagees cannot extinguish title of mortgagors under Land Reforms Act.

anchor.surface_text: The occupancy certificates, if any, given by the Special Mamlatdar to the appellants cannot under the provisions of the Land Reforms Act extinguish the title of the mortgagors.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act regulates Girasdar-tenant, not mortgage rights; no jurisdiction to affect title.

holdings.text: Rights of debtors/mortgagors in lands not extinguished under Land Reforms Act.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the right of the debtors in this case were not extinguished under the Land Reforms Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act targets Girasdar-tenant relations; mortgagees not tenants; no extinguishment without tenant status or compensation; payments/revenue no adverse title.

holdings.text: Court under Debtors Relief Act has jurisdiction to scale down debt, take accounts, and restore possession of mortgaged lands to mortgagors/debtors.

anchor.surface_text: it was open to the court exercising jurisdiction under the Debtors Relief Act to scale down the debt and provide for restoration of the land in possession of the mortgagees to the mortgagors

holdings.reasoning_summary: Debtors retain rights; Act governs debtor-creditor inter se rights including scaling and restoration after accounting.

holdings.text: No fault found with lower courts' award as modified directing restoration and payment of scaled debt; must be implemented.

anchor.surface_text: The right of the mortgagors not being extinguished under any provision of law to which our attention was drawn, no fault can be found, with the award as finally modified by the judgment of the Assistant Judge and effect must be given thereto.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Debtors' rights subsist; lower courts correctly applied Debtors Relief Act.

holdings.text: Not necessary to decide whether Debtors Relief Act overrides Land Reforms Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rights not extinguished under Land Reforms Act anyway; different objects.

holdings.text: Whether mortgagors as C class Girasdars can retain excess land post-restoration not for consideration in this case.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue beyond scope; not affecting decision on mortgage rights.
